name: admiralty
content:
the Admiralty
Add to word list

in the UK in the past, the government department responsible for the navy: The Admiralty questioned his fitness to lead the expedition. The British Admiralty ordered ships to carry supplies of lemon and lime juice to combat scurvy.
More examplesFewer examplesThe Admiralty had ordered that convoy ships should not pick up survivors if it endangered their own safety. At the beginning of 1793, Sir Charles Middleton, First Lord of the Admiralty, predicted that the new war with Revolutionary France would be "a war against trade".He argued landmark antitrust, libel, admiralty, and income tax cases over his 55-year legal career.Federal courts have jurisdiction over copyright cases, admiralty cases, lawsuits involving the military, immigration laws, and bankruptcy proceedings.
[ U ]
  law
  specialized the branch of law that deals with ships and shipping (= transporting things or people by sea): There are specialized rules in admiralty with regard to attacks on ferries and cruise ships. She sees arguments in favour of judicial specialization in some aspects of admiralty law. In a recent admiralty case, the marina storage contract was the focal point involving a personal injury to a boater.
